criteria: Understanding and identifying shared attributes among different categories of shapes (rhombuses, rectangles, etc.).
Recognizing rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals.
Drawing examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of the specified subcategories (rhombuses, rectangles, squares).
descriptions: The student does not demonstrate an understanding of shared attributes among different categories of shapes.
The student shows minimal understanding of shared attributes, with significant difficulty in identifying them.
The student identifies some shared attributes but struggles to articulate the relationship between shapes and their attributes.
The student identifies shared attributes among different categories of shapes and can explain the basic relationship.
The student demonstrates a solid understanding of shared attributes and explains how these attributes define larger categories of shapes.
The student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of shared attributes, clearly explaining how they define larger categories and providing insightful examples.
The student cannot recognize rhombuses, rectangles, or squares as quadrilaterals.
The student recognizes one or two of the shapes as quadrilaterals with prompting.
The student recognizes most of the shapes as quadrilaterals but struggles to explain why.
The student correctly identifies rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as quadrilaterals and provides a basic explanation.
The student confidently identifies the shapes as quadrilaterals and provides a clear explanation based on their attributes.
The student demonstrates a deep understanding by explaining the relationships between these shapes and quadrilaterals, including nuanced differences.
The student does not attempt or cannot draw a quadrilateral that doesn't belong to the specified subcategories.
The student attempts to draw a quadrilateral, but it either belongs to one of the subcategories or is not a quadrilateral.
The student draws a shape that is close to being a quadrilateral but has inaccuracies or resembles a subcategory.
The student draws a valid quadrilateral that does not clearly belong to the rhombuses, rectangles, or squares subcategories.
The student draws a clear and accurate example of a quadrilateral that does not belong to any of the specified subcategories.
The student draws multiple diverse and accurate examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to the specified subcategories, demonstrating a comprehensive understanding.
